image.altText: A woman stands behind two microphones in front of school with a serious look on face

props.synopsis: The NT opposition has criticised a government plan to direct unpaid truancy fines to be taken out of the Centrelink payments as a campaign of "fear and punishment" against parents and says the government doesn't have the jurisdiction to do it.Â

title.children: NT minister's plan to take truancy fines from Centrelink payments branded a 'scare tactic'

image.altText: A damaged, dark-coloured taxi in an impound.

props.synopsis: Police say the suspects are still at large amid calls for more to be done to address crime in the city.

title.children: Alice Springs taxis allegedly rammed, driver robbed twice in stolen ute rampage

image.altText: an image of a qantas plane

props.synopsis: An exclusive, invite-only Qantas high-flyers club now includes more than half of the new NT government frontbench, with the politicians all receiving membership as gifts.

title.children: 'A place of entitlement': New NT ministers given exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge memberships

image.altText: Close-up side profile of a man

props.synopsis: Lawyers for the NT Police Force have described one of their former officers as a "racist", "misogynist" and "narcissist, with grandiose ideas about his own abilities", at the inquest into the fatal police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: 'Racist, misogynist, homophobic': NT police lawyer makes explosive allegations about Zachary Rolfe at inquest

image.altText: a huge ship with beams and pipe-laying equipment

props.synopsis: Lawyers representing Tiwi Islanders trying to stop a gas pipeline running through their traditional sea country have been ordered to pay more than $9 million to gas giant Santos for its legal costs.

title.children: Lawyers for Tiwi Island group that tried to block gas project ordered to pay $9 million to Santos

image.altText: A woman's hands flick through a thick stack of paperwork.Â

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's Legal Aid Commission has been handed an almost $4 million funding boost, which will prevent looming service cuts that threatened to bring the territory's strapped justice system to its knees.

title.children: Funding lifeline handed to NT Legal Aid to prevent looming service cuts

image.altText: Darwin Port sign behind barbed wire.

props.synopsis: The PwC report found a "material uncertainty" about Landbridge's "ability to continue as a going concern" at the port.

title.children: Financial audit casts 'significant doubt' on Chinese-owned company's 99-year Darwin Port lease

image.altText: The coastline of a remote beach.

props.synopsis: Indigenous residents in West Arnhem Land have found eight suspected asylum seekers on the remote Cobourg Peninsula. It comes after a string of discoveries of foreign vessels in the area.

title.children: Group of suspected asylum seekers found on NT mainland, as community, government calls for more federal action

image.altText: A woman rests her head on another woman's shoulder.

props.synopsis: It was two days before Christmas when Mary Malbiynga's little sister was killed by her partner at Darwin's famous Mindil Beach.

title.children: Screams for 20 minutes and no help. Inside the NT's domestic violence tragedy

image.altText: Ryan Kobayashi and two women hold pictures of missing woman Hannah Kobayashi.

props.synopsis: Hannah Kobayashi vanished somewhere in LA while on her way from Hawaii to New York City, and her father died days after arriving to search for her, leading to wild theories from online sleuths as authorities continue their investigations.

title.children: On a layover in LA, Hannah vanished without a trace. Then came strange texts and worrying CCTV

image.altText: A man wearing a turban.

props.synopsis: Hezbollah chief Naim Qassem has declared his organisation has scored a "divine victory" in its year-long war with Israel that paused as part of a ceasefire deal last week.

title.children: Hezbollah chief says group has scored 'divine victory' against Israel

props.synopsis: New modelling reveals some outer reefs will stay 1 degree Celsius cooler than surrounding areas in coming decades -- but it's not clear how their coral colonies will fare.

title.children: Two cool spots found in the Great Barrier Reef where corals may survive warming oceans

image.altText: An image of a middle-aged woman wearing a bright blue dress with blonde hair, standing outside near trees.

props.synopsis: Melissa Yarnold, a transgender woman, says nobody should have to go through what she experienced while in custody.

title.children: 'Hell on Earth': Trans woman settles discrimination case after being held in men's prison

image.altText: Ross Coulthart in his home study holding his book: In Plain Sight.

props.synopsis: An institute, founded by an Australian-based entrepreneur, wants to better understand unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) and is funding research projects in the hope of answering the question, "Are we alone?"

title.children: Are we alone? Australian institute funds research into unexplained phenomena

image.altText: a group exercises on bikes at a weight loss camp

props.synopsis: Beijing has launched a three-year plan to tackle obesity, with rates of overweight children and adults rapidly increasing in just a few years.

title.children: 'They love kids to be chubby': China grapples with 'looming obesity crisis'

image.altText: A woman surrounded by other pro-independence demonstrators holds up a Kanak flag behind her back.

props.synopsis: The European power spends billions of euros on New Caledonia and faces a large damage bill from this year's violent unrest. Why is it hanging on?

title.children: Why one of Australia's closest neighbours remains valuable to this European power

image.altText: Mr Pavel and Mr Albanese shaking hands in a room

props.synopsis: Decorated former NATO military commander Petr Pavel says democratic nations need to cooperate more in the face of threats to Taiwan, Ukraine, and global free trade.

title.children: Visiting Czech President Petr Pavel urges democratic leaders to engage more with Taiwan

image.altText: Tow children walking amid tents in Gaza, one is holding a bucket and has his hand placed on younger sibling's back.

props.synopsis: Children in war-torn areas like Sudan and Gaza are suffering more than before, a new report suggests, as grave violations against them jump to the highest level we've seen in over two decades.

title.children: Children inside Gaza wish for an 'end to the war'. But their lives are more in danger now than for decades

image.altText: A phone screen showing social media apps.

props.synopsis: From the end of next year, children under 16 will be banned from social media in Australia. So how do parents feel about enforcing the nation's controversial new laws?

title.children: For some parents, the 'blanket rule' of Australia's under-16 social media ban can't come soon enough

image.altText: A shot of a busy Melbourne street with pedestrians in front of a tram.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 cases and hospitalisations have sharply risen in Victoria, with the wave of infection concerning health professionals going into summer.

title.children: COVID-19 wave hits Victoria, prompting calls for caution ahead of festive season

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses leaves a court house.

props.synopsis: A family member of the victims tells a Tasmanian court: "I didn't just lose my mum and brother â¦ I lost my family unit and I lost myself. I will never be me again."

title.children: Ex-police officer avoids jail time, suspended for driving for a year over crash that killed mother and son

image.altText: A woman holding the outstretched arm of a skeleton.

props.synopsis: Multiple female physiotherapists say they've experienced gender-based harassment while working for male sporting teams, often being the only woman in the change rooms.

title.children: Female physiotherapists experiencing gender-based harassment in male-dominated industry

image.altText: A woman stands infront of a rose bush holding a photo of her mother and father smiling

props.synopsis: Wendy Robinson's parents were shot dead 10 years ago. She is distressed their killer is starting to get some of his freedoms back and believes he is "being treated better" than his victims' family.

title.children: Murder victims' families say forensic patient reforms are needed to prevent day release for killers

image.altText: Two people play pool in an outback pub.

props.synopsis: When tree-changers Frank and Debbie Wust bought the pub that starred in Crocodile Dundee just over a decade ago, they had no idea it also meant helping to run an outback community.

title.children: In the outback, running a pub means more than pouring beers

image.altText: Scaffolding around the Notre Dame cathedral, backgrounded by blue sky

props.synopsis: The bells of Notre Dame are chiming again, but scaffolding still clinging to the cathedral's exterior is puzzling some Parisians.

title.children: Notre Dame is finally reopening after a devastating 2019 fire. But why does it still look unfinished?

image.altText: Bushfire smoke blows behind a series of beehives.

props.synopsis: As the fight against a massive bushfire north of Perth continues, honey producers have reported devastating losses to habitat critical for their bees.

title.children: 'That is all gone now': Honey producers say WA bushfire has incinerated critical bee habitat

image.altText: An Ireland player raises his arms in triumph after Ireland defeated South Africa at the men's Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Just the mention of Mack Hansen's name brings a beaming smile to the faces of his former Brumbies teammates, but they won't be showing him any favours when he fronts up against the Wallabies in Dublin.

title.children: Wallabies rue the 'one that got away' as they prepare to face Ireland's Aussie-born star

image.altText: A man in a blue jacket and black cap leans on a white post outside a building smiling

props.synopsis: Dong Yuyu has been published in several international publications and is well-respected around the world.

title.children: A Chinese journalist has been jailed for spying, prompting an outcry from his family and rights groups

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shir, black hat and sunglasses holding a carton of eggs in a field.

props.synopsis: Blasting AC/DC and sorting through hundreds of eggs is how Jinda Holland spends most of his working days. At 39, it is one of only a handful of jobs he has ever had and it is his favourite by far.

title.children: The chicken farm giving people living with disability a crack at the job market, one egg at a time

image.altText: Eight books covers sit on a pale background, including Niall Williams Time of the Child and Inga Simpson's The Thinning.

props.synopsis: If you're looking to stack up your summer reading pile, here's an excellent starting point, with new releases from Rosalie Ham, Lech Blaine, Haruki Murakami and more.

title.children: Planning a summer of great reading? Here are our recommendations

image.altText: A bettong wrapped inside a cream coloured soft bag

props.synopsis: After being driven to extinction in the area, these tiny brush-tailed bettongs were reintroduced to South Australia's Yorke Peninsula as part of an ambitious project to help nature heal itself â and evidence of their eco-engineering can already be seen.

title.children: The tiny engineers helping nature heal itself

image.altText: A composite image of AFLW players Jasmine Garner, Breanna Koenen, Kim  Rennie and Dakota Davidson.

props.synopsis: There are a lot of emotions that go into the lead up of a grand final. Here's how each side and their coaches are tackling them.

title.children: 'Narrative before the game': how one AFLW grand final coach fuels his side on emotion while the other ignores them

image.altText: Man sitting on stage beneath theatre lights

props.synopsis: Lighting crews say the new technology will provide the versatility needed to cater for hundreds of performances every year, ranging from symphony orchestras to touring rap artists.

title.children: 50,000-hour life span and 'extremely bright': Sydney Opera House's world-first state-of-the-art LED lights

image.altText: A woman in a pink shirt and glasses holds a newspaper.

props.synopsis: The Broken Hill Times rolled out its first edition during major power outages in the region as the Country Press Association says the regional print industry is getting stronger. Â Â

title.children: New Broken Hill Times newspaper disrupts narrative regional media on the way out

image.altText: A woman standing out the front of UK parliament

props.synopsis: The House of Commons' vote paves the way for assisted dying to be offered to those with terminal illnesses.

title.children: 'We need this': UK parliament backs voluntary assisted dying bill
